section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The security of the Proof of Process framework depends on several assumptions about the Attester's operating environment and the cryptographic primitives employed.

section.title: Attester Compromise
section.t: If the Attester's device key is compromised, an adversary can forge evidence packets. Mitigations include:

list.t: Hardware-bound keys stored in a TPM or Secure Enclave.
Key rotation with forward secrecy for evidence chains.
Device attestation certificates issued by the platform vendor.

section.title: Replay Attacks
section.t: An adversary may attempt to replay previously captured evidence packets. The VDF time-binding and session nonces prevent replay across sessions. Within-session replay is mitigated by the monotonic sequence numbers in each evidence packet and the chain hash linking consecutive packets.

section.title: Entropy Manipulation
section.t: An adversary may attempt to generate synthetic behavioral data that passes entropy checks. The framework mitigates this through multi-dimensional entropy analysis across timing, revision patterns, and pause distributions. A successful attack requires simultaneous forgery across all dimensions, which is computationally bounded by the forgery cost model in .

section.title: Relay Attacks
section.t: A relay attack involves an adversary capturing evidence from a legitimate authorship session and presenting it as evidence for a different document. Content binding (the cryptographic hash of document state at each evidence window) prevents this attack, as the evidence is tied to specific content transitions.
